all_paragraphs: Part 2: Design your own neural network

Images are very easy for us, as a human, to understand. We are able to identify if an image is a dog or a cat, if an image has a red ball or calculate the number of people in an image. These tasks are not so easy for a computer.
Computer vision allows your computer to understand images. But how?
Why don’t we use instance segmentation for every single task?

Every model has its own trade-offs. The more complex it is, the slower and more expensive it is. The simpler it is, the faster and cheaper it is. It will not make sense to use the most expensive instance segmentation if you simply want a program to detect if there is a ball in an image.

It is insane to develop your own computer vision model from scratch for practical use. Why spend hours and tons of money on building your own model when you can achieve better results with models that have been pre-trained by researchers?
MXNet is an open-sourced deep learning framework. MXNet provides a high-level API called Gluon. Gluon provides several toolkits for several tasks:

GluonCV provides implementations of state-of-the-art (SOTA) deep learning algorithms in computer vision. It aims to help engineers, researchers, and students quickly prototype products, validate new ideas and learn computer vision.

GluonCV has tons of models that have been fine-tuned by well-known institutes and researchers with a copious amount of data collected over several years using an unimaginable amount of computing power and time. All the pre-trained models are housed inside GluonCV in Model Zoo.
After this article, you should be able to conduct all 4 computer vision tasks with GluonCV and MXNet.

Semantic segmentation aims to classify every pixel in an image. It will look at the full context of the image before making segment level prediction. After which, the model will use different colours to overlay all the pixels of an image to separate them by class. In this section, background classes are labelled as -1.
This section will use FCN ResNet ADE, which is a fully connected neural network with ResNet architecture that is trained on the ADE20K dataset.

ToTensor() changes your image from HWC to CHW format and the data type from 8-bit integer to 32-bit float. The image is then normalised according to the ImageNet one case statistics.
As mentioned earlier, we usually predict images batches by batches. Even though we are only predicting 1 single image, we still have to specify the batch size:
To speed things up, we will apply .demo to our network. The longer version can be found under instance segmentation.
There is only 1 image, 150 predicted classes, and the image has a width of 576 and height of 768.
Now, let’s colour our image to segment them:
Instance segmentation is able to identify that one person is different from another person. Instead of a boundary box, we can predict the exact boundary and colour of those pixels.
Congratulations! You managed to complete the 4 main computer vision tasks using only a single framework!
Do try out different models and determine which is the best for you. Remember: A more complex model is not necessarily the best model.

Understanding business requirements is very important. Choose the model that best fits your purpose. There is always a trade-off. Spend some time looking through the documentation to determine which model architecture and which class labels best suits your needs.
